Elmer Livingston MacRae (American, 1875–1955). Battleships at Newport, 1912. Oil on canvas. Sewell C. Biggs Museum of American Art, Dover, Delaware.

data.title: The Wave, c. 1912
data.collection: Gift of Dr. Daniel D. Van De Grift, 1922.86
data.description: As a sculptor of allegorical and mythological figures, Chester Beach’s aesthetic was rooted in classical tradition. The Wave, however, with its more contemporary treatment of the figure’s hairstyle and posture, reveals that the artist could also portray figures in a less traditional manner. Beach exhibited four works at the Armory Show in New York, but because the Chicago presentation was physically limited, as an American he was allowed only one submission. He chose to present himself as a more modern artist in Chicago: The Wave was the only work of the four that did not depict a mythological subject.
data.citation: Chester Beach (American, 1881–1956). The Wave, c. 1912. Bronze; 78.7 × 37.5 × 31.8 cm (31 × 14 3/4 × 12 1/2 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Dr. Daniel D. Van De Grift, 1922.86.
Edward Middleton Manigault (American, 1887-1922). The Clown, 1912. Oil on canvas; 86.4 x 63.2 cm (34 x 24 7/8 in.). The Columbus Museum of Art. Museum purchase, Howald Fund.
